abstract: Edward J Snowden arrives in Moscow from Hong Kong, as American officials press Russia to turn him over on charges of espionage; has been aided in his escape by Wikileaks and is considering potential destinations including Ecuador; frustrated Obama administration warns countries in Latin America not to harbor Snowden or allow him passage, escalating international hunt that threatens to strain relations on three continents.
snippet: Edward J. Snowden arrived in Moscow on Sunday as American officials pressed Russia to turn him over and warned countries in Latin America not to harbor him or allow him passage.

byline.contributor: Peter Baker reported from Washington, and Ellen Barry from Moscow. Reporting was contributed by Scott Shane, Steven Lee Myers and Charlie Savage from Washington; Keith Bradsher from Hong Kong; Michael R. Gordon from Doha, Qatar; Rick Gladstone from New York; and Andrew Roth from Moscow.

snippet: From government agencies to corporate America, there is a renewed emphasis on thwarting the rogue I.T. employee.

headline.main: F.B.I. Is Broadening Surveillance Role, Report Shows
headline.print_headline: F.B.I. Broadening Surveillance Role, Report Shows

abstract: Justice Dept's classified study reveals that FBI has from 2008 onwards become increasingly involved with running government's surveillance program, which is most often associated with National Security Agency; redacted version of report has been made available due to Freedom of Information Act suit filed by The New York Times.
snippet: Since 2008, the bureau has been assuming a larger role in the government’s warrantless surveillance program, according to a newly declassified report.

lead_paragraph: A federal study found that there was no reliable way to get at the communications of terrorism suspects without sweeping up records of every call in the United States.

headline.main: Report Finds No Substitute for Mass Data Collection
headline.print_headline: Report Finds No Substitute for Mass Data Collection

abstract: Federal study points to lack of viable alternative to bulk collection of telephone call records as means of intercepting communication of terrorists, even as civil rights advocates contend that such practices are intrusive; findings, which cast doubt on technological solution to problem, come year after Pres Obama announced moderate reforms to National Security Agency collection practices.
snippet: A federal study found that there was no reliable way to get at the communications of terrorism suspects without sweeping up records of every call in the United States.

lead_paragraph: There is no explanation of why, in 2008, the vast collection of messages was sucked into the global system of electronic surveillance created and maintained by British and American spies.

headline.main: British Spies Seized Emails to Reporters
headline.print_headline: British Spies Seized Emails to Reporters

abstract: Newly disclosed classified document shows that British intelligence services intercepted email messages to journalists for at least dozen international media organizations at end of 2008, as well as emails sent to United Nations officials and thousands of other people; document is part of trove leaked by Edward J Snowden.
snippet: There is no explanation of why, in 2008, the vast collection of messages was sucked into the global system of electronic surveillance created and maintained by British and American spies.
